reviewText:
If you like tabletop games then you HAVE to like this game. It simulates a tabletop and you have to follow the rules for the game, so house rules are accepted here. Also it's an easy way to get together with friends for a few games when you can't schedule a game night. They keep adding in features to make sure the game matches up with what you need to play diffent games, like blindfolding, teams, and even scripting so someone else can make things easier for you by writing that script. Hosting a server is built in, there is kick and ban options, the only thing this game is missing is an FOV slider, but you don't need one. the FOV is fine. I have nothing bad to say about this game.

Pros: everything

Cons: none

Fantastic in theory and execution.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tabletop simulator is a game that has everything in the title.

1. I immediately went on the workshop for it and found Cards Against Humanity, with 4 core sets included and more coming in.

2. You can make anything. friend made hexagonal chess in a while, as it's a real chess variant that was famous in britain.

3. Played CAH with friend and lots of people joined, and we carried that into a 4 player chess game when it ended.

4. You can flip the table at any point. And then undo it.

5. It controls amazingly. you can zoom in to the cards, make them smaller/bigger, put them on the side, put them into your hand, flip them to hide them (it autohides if it's in your hand, only you can see it)

6. Went onto the workshop and found an exact recreation of an 80's boardgame for the first Legend Of Zelda game, complete with instruction booklet. 10/10 playing that tomorrow

It supports a lot of people, and it has voice chat too.

Edit: forgot to say you can make your own boards, card sets, and anything
and rules for each variant are on the side, and you can just click a button to see them all

We played uno
10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the most simple and yet most ingenius ideas I have ever seen and I recommend it whole heartedly. If the idea of playing almost any board game you can think of over the internet appeals to you then pick this game up now.

This game has allowed me to play games ive never gotten a chance to play before and I have a lot of fun just browsing the rooms and seeing whats being played. There are no rules, you just sit down and play.

This game is also amazing as a simple tool for building your own games. Im a game designer and this game lets me make virtual versions of my games that I could potentally use for playtesting. I could playtest my games from the comfort of my own home. And with eventual Steam Workshop support this could be a truely amazing thing.

There are a few kinks that need working out. The custom board and card features could be a little more user friendly but there totally usable and I imagine it will get worked out in later patches.

As a hobbist or even a creative mind this game is a must buy. If the idea of bringing all your friends from around the world together for a game of Monopoly sounds awesome to you then pick this up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Want to play something original with your friends?
Want to play with your friends and family without buying a bunch of board and card games outside?
Want to create board and card games?
How about playing with others online (total of 8 players) and learn new games?
Bored of other games?

GET THIS GAME!

Pros:
- Has a variety of tabletop games
- Easy to learn controls
- Can create custom cards, boards, pieces, figurines, and tables
- Host a multiplayer server without portforwarding
- Save a game you made in singleplayer and share on the workshop or with online players
- Become a Game Master and control how a game is played
- Do things on the tablet

Cons:
- Important to have some friends or family to play with you, or find a game on the server browser
- Still some bugs and glitches, but nothing major
- When host leaves, the server is closed and everyone is kicked
- Rewind or undo button shuffles your hand if you're playing card games that involves some kind of organization

tl;dr
Good and fun game with friends or online players, though there are a few minor problems that stook out to me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

We played four-player Settlers of Catan last night.  No built-in rule handling or anything, just the board, dice, stacks of cards, whatever, and occasionally we did silly things like pick up whole stacks of cards or forget to collect resources or knock over the Robber token moving stuff around...and I have to say it was a hell of a lot more fun than if the game rules were implemented and automatic.  The whole thing felt very human.  Also we spent a lot of time drawing ♥♥♥♥♥ on the table waiting for our turns to come around.

I don't think I'd want to try playing this with people I don't know well, especially internet pickup games, but for people I don't see often enough in person but still want to hang out with, definitely A++++++ would act like a dork again.  You definitely need to use the tutorial to have any idea what the controls are since they're not _that_ intuitive, but that only takes like five minutes and then you're good.  I mean there's only so many buttons you can press to move pieces around a table.

Sometimes our voice chat transmission dropped out--on two different machines, so not a fluke of my hardware.  Not sure what's up with that.  Also I feel like it would be really tedious trying to set this up for RPG stuff, like setting up all the fancy walls etc.  But that's super tedious in the real world too, and you can set things up ahead of time and save the table to reload later, so I guess it works.

Currently looking at importing a bunch of custom models and seeing how well that works.  We need to have a tea party!

...I'm probably up for gaming with people I know any time.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Allows you to play any board game or card game with people not in the same room.

That's the pitch and it's a big one. However, the implementation knocks it out of the park.

At it's core Table Simulator  is, well a table (duh) that you have complete control over. Whether you're manipulating cards, placing models,  rolling dice, control is easy intuitive and tight. This places Table Simulator as a prime candidate for modding.

And it has flourished, players have imported every card and board game under the sun to be played with others online and all they had to do is import the art assets. Just like playing a physical version the players themselves manage the game mechanics, no additional scripting or AI is needed, only the players themselves are needed.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWell worth the price.  Tabletop Simulator is basically what the name implies.  Almost any game that can be played on a tabletop, whether it be chess, checkers, Magic the Gathering, D&D, Cards Against Humanity, or whatever you want, the controls and graphics make it feel real.  The mods definitely make this game enjoyable.

Just like playing a physical version the players themselves manage the game mechanics, no additional scripting or AI is needed, only the players themselves are needed.

reviewText: Most replayable game on steam

reviewText:
TL;DR
Great to play board games with your online friends, without the extra hassle of setting up.

Score

✰82%✰

Pros

Thousands of Board Games
Massive replay value

Cons

Controls are fiddly
Not all mods get updated

Gameplay:


Tabletop simulator is a dream come true for anyone who has ever loved engaging in board games, and just can't find the company to play them with. The core aspect relies on mod-based contributions, like Garry's Mod – except for tabletop games. There are thousands to choose from, ranging from things like RISK, Monopoly, Cards Against Humanity – to Chess and countless other party style board games.


Some mods are intricately rendered with original skins for playing pieces, others are cleverly designed and planned out. There are original games, and a good chance to find any of the board games you've loved back at home or for those times where you're forced to put up with extra relatives.


The initial premise, of course, is that you're presented with a table, faced against a randomly generated background (which incidently is also moddable.) Depending on if you choose a private or open game will decide if you play with your friends or with strangers. I would probably recommend playing with friends, as there is a high tendancy for random players to “flip” the table, which consequently ruins the progress of whatever is there.


The controls of Tabletop can take a little getting used to, since sometimes a wrong movement can accidentally sabotage things that you don't want sabotaged, or reveal your card hand. (Which then makes you flip the table because it was a really good hand.) This is probably my only real gripe – the chance of a game being killed before it hits the real action, and the fiddly controls. Also, perhaps, people who have excellant mods but don't update them, or don't include rules with their games. :(


The gameplay offered is whatever mods you choose to download and whenever you find people who will want to sit around and play all those classic party games. I played Pictogram! Cards Against Humanity, Uno, Threeway Chess and WoW Guess Who! In one session with a few other friends.


It's brilliant to be able to pick through the list and agree on games together without doing the packing and unpacking that goes beforehand with physical board games. Obviously there's something special about doing that as well, but when your friends live across the map, this is the perfect opportunity to get them together and tackle that desire to find people willing to sit around long enough for board game sessions.

Want moar? Click here to join my steam group and Click here to follow my curator page!

reviewText:
I was able to play Eels and Escalators. 100/10, would play Eels and Escalators again!

In all seriousness, this game is great for people who don’t have any friends in real life. Even if you do have friends, the game is still pretty great!! Anyway, I went into this game expecting it to be pretty bad. Well, not really “bad”, more like stupid. I expected it to be pretty stupid. However, after some “experimentation” – we’ll say “experimentation”, but you can call it whatever you’d like – I’ve been having a lot of fun with it. I love board games, you see… Yeah, I know; who doesn’t love board games, right? Anyway, I like board games a lot and I like playing board games. My problem is, the group I usually play with doesn’t like the “complexity” of the games I usually tend to like playing. I use the term “complexity” loosely because my games aren’t very “complex”, but they are more complex than say something like Uno, Monopoly, or Skip-Bo. Anyway, I’m starting to digress. Point being, the game is great and you should play it if you’re either:
A.	Into board games
B.	Into board games and don’t have anybody to play with
C.	Into board games and have anybody/somebody to play with
D.	Into board games (again)… This game is just great!
E.	Or if you just like good games.

Oh, and don’t let the name Tabletop SIMULATOR fool you… This is by far the best SIMULATOR out there, or at least one of the best.

reviewText:
I think I really underestimated how good this game could be before I bought it. I honestly thought it was just some kind of joke after seeing all the table flipping videos and thought it would just be a physics simulator. The possibilites in this game are quite literally endless. I've already played Tokaido, Chinese Checkers, Blackjack and Snakes and Ladders. This is a really good simulator because it's actually so much like real life and you don't have to spend loads of money on the real thing. Even the drawing mechanics make this enjoyable alone. You can play pen & paper games like Tic Tac Toe, Hangman or Dots and Boxes.

I thought I might not have enjoyed this game prior to buying it because a lot of videos suggested that you need friends for it to work but playing on random servers worked the best for me as this game has one of the best communities I've ever seen.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The idea behind this game is pretty fantastic.  You can scan in your favorite family game board, upload models of the pieces on the workshop, and it will be completely playable.  With the sandbox environment, anything you can do with your tabletop at home, you can potentially do here.

Unfortunately, most of the games on the server list are locked, and the few that are open are not very well coordinated.

I recommend this game as something to play with friends who also own it, but not as something that can be easily jump into without them.

I've also had problems with the Linux version crashing when selecting from a menu consensually, but the game is early access after all.

reviewText:
I remember seeing this game being featured on the Steam Store. After that, I immediately bought it for myself, and a copy for a friend.
Tabletop Simulator has nice physics, and perfect gameplay. Although this was a game about playing games, which let you throw pieces around and screw up the board, playing games is easy, as the game will correct your piece to the nearest slot when you set down a game piece.
The game already comes with a few different modes, such as Chess, Checkers, Chinese Checkers, RPG set, Reversi, Poker, Solitaire, etc. Along with these different modes, the modding community on the Steam Workshop makes new content for my friends and I to play, and constantly adds to the amount of gameplay content for the game. I've downloaded many mods, such as 3 player chess, Risk, Battle of Burgundy, and many more.
At some point, I tried to convince another friend to buy it, but he refused, so I just gifted a copy to him.
Tabletop Simulator is a great game, with all types of board games packed into one video game. I would absolutely recommend this to a friend.

reviewText: Imagine your favorite board game, in 3D, on your PC, with legit multiplayer. No more wasting time resetting props or putting anything away. A lot of famous board games are available on the workshop including Monopoly and Scrabble. Oddly enough this game also includes a set of tools: A calculator, a tablet that has a built in web browser based on chrome, a digital clock, notes, even a music player that looks like a common MP3 player. These tools can be spawned in multiplayer by the host which can be very helpful.\n\nIt's very well optimised, doesn't eat ram and doesn't overstress your graphics card. Me and my friend spent 7 hours playing board games when I got the game last night(12/22/2015). I gotta say, I'm impressed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has very few flaws, the most annoying one would really be how the multiplayer was coded. There's quite a bit of lag when you move many objects and it gets even worse if the host has a bad connection.

The Steam Workshop has almost any board game you can think of and making your own custom content is as easy as searching Google Images for the board you want and paste the link to the image in the game.

People don't tend to join empty rooms so hosting a game that not many play/know can be hard.

There's no way to stop someone from griefing if they so desire, other than straight up ban them.

Overall, these flaws are very minor and almost everything else you'd expect is already in the game and well done.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A physics-based sandbox where you manipulate objects  to your liking. Play Poker, Backgammon, Checkers, Chess, and a handful of other games by default! Download mods for the game to play your favorite card and board games including: Pokemon Trading Card Game, Cards Against Humanity, Risk, Munchkin, Clue, etc.

This game is best when played with friends, but is still fun when playing with strangers due to the built-in voice communication which actually sounds pretty good.

Grow and shrink objects to your heart's content, knock everything over with a giant hydra that takes up the whole table! Lost a hand at Texas Hold Em'? Flip the table. Win a hand at Texas Hold Em'? Flip the table. Someone flip the table? Flip the table.

Trolling in this game is as fun as playing the actual game itself.

The possibilities are endless with the new Steam Workshop integration. There will be even more games added, and a bunch of awesome looking objects to be released in time!

I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this! It's so great getting to play board/card games with people all over the world. The controls take some getting used to since it's just a physics engine, but once you get the hang of it it's great. I have yet to try out making my own game, but just the fact that you can is awesome. It's also incredibly good as a way to try games before you buy them or simply just to play them. I mean, this is still doesn't come close to actually physically playing a game in person, but let's face it; games are damn expensive. Tabletop stuff usually runs $30 each minimum, often more, and it isn't always easy getting people over to play. My only problem with this game is that most of the workshop is copyrighted games.... which I will honestly still use while they are available but I wish there were a legit alternative since favorites like Munchkin get frequenty removed due to copyright claims. Berserk Games needs to try getting partnerships or deals with the actual game creators to allow us to use assets for free or a reasonable price. It won't stop the fan-made copies from popping up, but I'm sure others besides me would be ok with a fair price in exchange for it remaining easilly available.

TL;DR: Incredibly awesome game, but needs permissions from copyright holders to stop workshop content from being removed!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you've ever wanted to just sit down with some friends, play some games, toss some cards around, build with blocks, flip tables, this game's got you covered. Tabletop Simulator is very close to the real experience of just sitting around with friends but online (without the hassle of picking pieces off the ground everytime your friends knock them down). I've had a lot of fun with this game so far just generally messing around with the physics system, playing D&D, building sets, rolling dice and the sorts. It's great for me and my friends to get together and play like we used to since we all moved to different parts of the world and it can be great for anyone else too. The modding community also really brings this game to life and the ability to make pictures and models and add them to the game with relative ease gives it some great replayability. Albeit there being a few bugs, which is to be expected from early access things have run fairly smoothly and I plan on getting back to it soon! Great buy for anyone who wants to recreate that experience of sitting around the table with friends, but online!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A simple, yet elegant, this game is a genuine Tabletop Simulator.
You and your friends can sit around the table and interact with all the pieces on the table, making this more of a sandbox game than anything else.
Yes, you can spawn a deck of cards, but what you do with it is up to you. I have a feeling that just about any tabletop game can be played in this.

Being physics based, it feels good to roll your dice, mess with other peoples tokens and toss items off the table in furious rage!

Strangely enough, for a game with such a simple concept, it gets lots of regular updates with bug fixes, changes and new content. You can (for example) now add your own custom pugs by using the URL of some character or monster’s image. You can display a grid on one of the many different tables and have pieces align to it. You can spawn in a bag, drop things in it, shake it and pull them randomised out. You can apply a different colour to just about everything and more!

Using the Steam Workshop, it is very mod-friendly and spawned a very active modding community with modders adding in new games, models and all sorts of stuff!

I use this program a lot for my Dungeons and Dragons sessions and had a lot of fun in it.

If the idea of having a virtual tabletop doesn’t interest you, you shouldn’t buy this game. If it does however, you can’t go wrong with the versatility of Tabletop Simulator.

My only real gripe with this game is that the UI doesn’t feel right, but other than that it is everything you expect it to be and more.

reviewText:
Tabletop Simulator is a hilarious but realistic game which has you trying to create something resembling a game only for someone to come in and flick it all into pieces.
There's multiple good things about this game:
+ Lots of Servers to play on
+ Singleplayer if you're feeling anti-social
+ Too much workshop
+ At least 2000 different games you can create with basic set
+ Cards against Humanity will probably be on the list of servers
+ Graphics are nice
But also a few cons:
- The troll players who come in to destroy your game
- Costs more than in the Beta (it cost £11.99 before)
- Poker table angles are a bit broken

However, because I got this game in the Beta I got it for £11.99.
There's also a setting for blocking access to everything, stopping those naughty trolls.
So, overall, this game is one to play if you want tableflipping madne- I, um, mean, fun!
9.4/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game fits any persons desire to play board games and card games.  It comes highly reccomended, but you must realize thtat right now it is still in Early Access and the game has many flaws.  Some of which right now include occasional hard lag spikes, limited boards, and RPG options. However, it has come very apparent that Berserk games is very hell bent on making this work, so I would not be scared of this turning into a no full release early access game like many in this genre.
Tabletop Simulator is wonderful in so many ways.  If your like me, Board Games are super fun but harder to get people to come around a table just to play them.  Tabletop Simulator is full of people from all sorts of places ready to play a simple universal game like checkers and chess.  What I love the most is the RPG options, although limited, are still in the game.  I always wanted to DnD, so this makes it easier to get into it without having to buy a bunch of peices. They do plan on expanding these options as well as many more.
Finally, the biggest apeal to Tabletop Simulator is the costumization features.  People are playing ONLINE games of Uno, Monoply, and the very popular Cards Against Humanity in mere seconds.  I have also found people making their own boards or making their own games with the features in the game and playing their own wacky crap online.
Overall, Tabletop Simulator comes highly reccomended to anyone.  The creativity is flowing more and more everyday from the users, and the game has only just begun.

reviewText:
A very robust engine for letting you play tabletop games with your friends online.

A review for this game is not especially helpful as I can only really review the engine itself, and whether or not you have fun comes down to if you can use the program in the right way.  A game played in Tabletop Simulator is only as good as the mod creator made it to be.  A TRPG is only going to be as fun as the people you play with.  That's just how it works.

Your first step should be to look at the Steam Workshop for a few games you might be looking to play with your friends, or think about which you might want to work on yourself.  I myself added a mod to the workshop for a now-defunct CCG, and it wasn't too hard.  Adding some resources for modding could be an important improvement from the devs, but with a little elbow grease, reddit / steam forum searching, and google you can find the answers you need without difficulty.

If you've got some tabletop games you want to play online, this is the tool for you.  Still receives regular updates too.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=305502693
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Played Avalon Hill's Betrayal at House on Haunted Hill (distributed by Wizards of the Coast) with my LP buddies, and had a real blast. The only complexity with this comes from the actual game rules of whatever you decide to play - the simulator itself is simple, easy to use, and very straightforward with its presentation.

The mod community is great, and it's thanks to all their hard work that we have as many games to play as we do!

10/10, will play again.

Anyone who has never played Betrayal at House on Haunted Hill before should really do so, as an aside. It's a wondrous game! As of this review, only the first edition is available from the steam workshop as a tabletop simulator mod, which unfortunately contains misprints and vague rules, and other minor errors. Hopefully modders will whip up the revised Second Edition soon!

If you're a hardcore gamer, there's a table flip option.

Absolutely well worth the $20.

So, overall, this game is one to play if you want tableflipping madne- I, um, mean, fun!
9.4/10

reviewText:
So... I'm on a server with a couple of Real life friends when we decided to do some jigsaw puzzles for kicks. We Found some random pictures off the internet to assemble and everything was going pretty smoothly. Then, SOMEONE found a glorious picture of an ever so slightly man in an ogre-sized orange clog. We spent AGES assembling it. It was worth it.

Alas, one of the friends had to depart, but he was swiftly replaced by a respectable gentleman none of us knew. However, this fine chap happened to join in the middle of us assembling a rather... interesting, shrek puzzle.

Turns out this dude was pretty good at creating shrek.

Shrek is love
date:
Shrek is life" we all chanted in chat in unison.

So would I recommend this game?

Yes. For Shrek puzzles.

It's all ogre now."

reviewText: Simulator games have frequently been a bit of a joke to a lot of people.  There's a reason why Goat Simulator is so popular after all, so much so that certain devs are starting to look at the name Simulator" with a bit of hesitation.  On the surface
date: a few people might think that Tabletop Simulator is a bit of a joke as well due to some of the things it offers(Flipping the table
hoursPlayed: etc)
voteText:
but what it offers honestly makes it worth the price and shows that it's more than just a silly little thing.

Graphics:
Tabletop Simulator's graphics
helpfulPercent: as a whole
votesHelpful: are simple.  They look good enough that they'll get the job done but they won't be winning any awards.  The game allows you to import models and textures
votesTotal: so your mileage may vary
votesFunny: as well.  The backdrop for the "rooms" use a 4800x2400 HDRI Panorama shot
commentsCount: which means seams won't be an issue.  Overall
column16:
passable for what needs to be done.

Gameplay:
Tabletop Simulator is
column18: a game used to simulate various tabletops.  You start off with a decent number of standard board and card games
column19: most pretty typical for what you'd see.  They're nice
column20: but not exactly something I'd pay 20$ for flat out(But I'm a bit stingy)
column21: although the ability to play in a system that's not automated is nice.\n\nThat leads into my next point:  The game isn't automated for the most part.  Everything is pretty customizable
column22: and you can do various things
column29: if not all of it being able to be changed for your benefit(Of particular note is that you can disable the Table Flip option
column30:
thank god).  Leading to a pretty fun experience of just sitting around a table and BS'ing with friends.

My one MAJOR issue with the gameplay is that you cannot peek at a card while it is face down outside of moving it into a hidden zone(Which is a bit cumbersome) or returning it to your hand(Which has its own fair share of complications)

Workshop Support:
This game allows you to create objects
column32: and use them to make your own various games.  The system of doing so is relatively simple
column33: as long as you know your way around models and textures
column35: allowing you to import your own models into the game as well.  This is where the game shines
column36: as almost any card or board game is possible with what is given to you.  The little figure can even be given animations for attacking and the like
column37: to simulate an RPG.\n\nAlong with that
column38: there are various tools inserted in the game to help you accomplish this.  From counters
column42: and more.  And ALL of this can be uploaded and downloaded from the Steam Workshop
column43: with download times being reduced due to the ability of Tabletop Simulator streaming image content from a hosted site(Which is both a blessing and a curse
column45: all of it is really nice
column46: my only problem with the modular ability of this game is that it seems like you can't plug your own MP3s into the MP3 player and you can't import custom tables
column48:
as that would have made RPGs truly perfect for this system.  Both of these can be worked around but it leads to an experience that is less than perfect.

Overall:
At the end of the day
column49: Tabletop Simulator is a great game that allows people to just instantly pick up a deck or a pair of dice and play their favorite games.  It isn't perfect
column50: and it won't ever be a true replacement for sitting around a table with your friends
column51: but for those who are separated by long distances
column52: this is a great alternative that will be sure to keep everyone happy.  It has a few issues but it's constantly being updated and I hope these will be sorted out in time.  Something else I want to note is that
column53: while the DLC is a bit heavily priced
column54: only one person needs to own it
column55: which is..pretty much how it goes in real life
column56: so I really appreciate and respect that.\n\nOverall
column58: and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone."

reviewText:
A tabletop physics engine allowing more control for an organized social event than tools for griefers; anyone joining a game can slap the cards out of your hand, but the host can almost instantly ban, and reverse the damage done by rewinding time.

Everything works really intuitively, objects snap and cascade by physically stacking, like chips and cards. Dice rolls with satisfying thuds like 45 grams of the finest plastic four sided cube on 19th century rosewood table. And if you highlight multiple dice, it tallies the total for you.

All game states can be saved and loaded, by any of the 8 players joined, with permissions allowed by the host ofcourse. With integrated voice chat, turn indicators, handzones and private zones for hiding your hand/dice, it brings a lot of games to the table. Also, all types of objects can be customized with its own models, physics, and textures.

The game grants you objects like cards, poker chips, coins, dice (d3, d4, d6, d20, etc.,) and figurines (chess/d&d). Objects snap and cascade by physically stacking, like chips and cards. You can shuffle cards by just pressing R, animation takes less than a second and is heard by all players. Then you can deal to everyone's hand just by clicking a button. Where the host controls the permissions of how every player interacts with the environment with a dropdown checklist. With a maximum of 8 players, it is really multiplayer tabletop games.

Also, there’s a tablet simulator that links to google and youtube, that can be seen by every player on the table. Movie/music night?

The advance features, like tape measurements, allows accuracy POV/LOS action figure games, like Warhammer 40k to be simulated perfectly. All you need is a brain for storing the codex rules, and the figurines available on the mod page. You measure 6” for walking infantry, toss a grenade and borrow the 3” blast marker available on the workshop page. When you shoot, you just lower your camera onto the table, and get an accurate Line of Sight from the space marine’s point of view.

Game's good.

reviewText:
This is one of the best purchases I have ever made. I bought this on Winter Sale 2015 for $10 and have definitely gotten my money worth. I thought I would have to convince my friends to get it to have a good time but it turns out the community playing it is awesome. I have yet to find myself trying to find a game and not succeeding. Additionally, it is very easy to host games and people almost always join and play with me!

I've created a few mods which was relatively simple.

My main complaint is that the controls are a little bit difficult to learn and I wish some of the functionality could be mapped to keyboard. However, once you figure it out it becomes second nature and the controls no longer get in the way.

If you're worried about dropping the money to get this and not being able to find people to play with, don't worry, the community is awesome and you will be playing games right away. Additionally, everyone is extremely friendly. However, make sure you have a microphone as it is *almost* required to play most games. There is text chat but very few people use it.

reviewText:
I can't even begin to express how great this game is.

Want to play chess but none of your friends or family play it? You have Table Top Simulator.

Want to play Eels and Escalators from Spongebob but it doesn't exist? You have Table Top Simulator.

Want to play Monopoly but don't want to tear your family apart? You have Table Top Simulator.

Want to play Magic: The Gathering but don't have the money for cards? You have Table Top Simulator.

Literally any board game that has ever existed, and new ones people have created, you can play on Table Top Simulator as well as card games like uno, cards against humanity, poker, blackjack, and more. You can play with your friends, but if they don't have the game you can play people online. This game is unlimited fun and has infinite things to do, and you will never get tired of it.

Less than 2 weeks into having this game and it is already my 4th most played out of 71 games.

reviewText:
Tabletop Simulator is the quintessential computer program for virtual computer rendering and computing of a real world tabletop. I find this the perfect piece of software for those who cannot afford a real tabletop. I don't just mean your kitchen countertop. No; this game, with its genius programming and opitmization in tandem with your graphics card, calculating hundreds of millions of different floating point operations quicker than you can blink an eye, has the ability to simulate just about any kind of tabletop.

Mahogany? Of course.

Fine Grain Oak? Even Call of Duty can do that. C'mon.

Oil-Treated Maple with a Spruce Trim? You bet your buttons it can simulate that.

Round Glass with an Angled Trim? Yessiree, even non wood materials!

Reverse Grain Ash Wood with a Thin Veneer? Possiby, if you've got that new GTX 980 or whatever.


This is perfect for those who cannot afford these fine pieces of art many may refer to as tabletops" in the real world
date: or for those people who wish to expand thier horizons and experience different types of tabletops and don't have the extra money or space in real life to spend on such glorius tabletops."

reviewText:
A good test of Tabletop Simuator on Steam is . . . can it handle the various game elements of a classic social board game like Cosmic Encounter® and is the Tabletop Simulator evironment a place where the game can be played easily and naturally, just like you were sitting at a table playing a game of Cosmic with your friends?

It can and does. Passing with flying colors! Plus you can play with anyone anywhere in the world at anytime, talk to and hear other players, save games to complete later, and bring in your own homebrew aliens to test and play.

As one of the original designers of Cosmic Encounter I am thankful for all the skill and hard work by Berserk Games to create this wonderful environment for our game.

Also, a note for game designers - this is a perfect environment to use for creating and play testing new game concepts.

reviewText:
Had low expectations, but I was pleasantly surprised! This game is so good that I've spent well over $100 on it already on buying it for others to enjoy. 9/10, would be perfect if some bugs were fixed, mainly in matchmaking and ping. The issues are usually resolved by entering/exiting the server, and port forwarding helps a tonne. Expect a lot from this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Digital media has made another game of something that you should do in real life with Tabletop Simulator. Except you can't alter gravity in real life. The game is pretty much a board game simulator that lets you play board games. Yea. That's it. BUT THERE'S MORE! The steam workshop features tons of mods of games that you can find in real life, or games that don't even exist. You can play with random people you find on the servers, or you can mess with friends. If I'm going to be honest, playing with people that you know is the best way to play this game.
LIST OF THINGS YOU CAN DO IN THIS GAME THAT YOU CAN'T IN REAL LIFE:
-Spawn dozens of copies of Space Jam.
-Change gravity.
-Grab every piece on a chessboard at once.
-Flip tables and get away with it.
-Play a collection of board games that don't exist.
-Ruin a game that you find boring with ease.
AND MORE!
If you are too lazy to set up a board game in real life, set one up in Tabletop Simulator!
WARNING: If your friend is overly competetive, they may become emo. Be warned.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Good:  I've only mucked about on this for about 10 minutes so far, and yes, this IS an Early Access game, but so far, I see this as a WONDERFUL tool for table top gamers (board games, RPG's, miniatures, etc).  From what I've seen on the Forums, the Devs are going to update content (a tape measure is one of the ones they've talked about...for miniature gaming), so this is going to add even more variation to the creation and game play.  I love the physics involved in the game, things like picking up and moving the pieces, shuffling cards, rolling dice, and even flipping the table (yes...that flipping the table).

The Bad:  It's Early Access...it's effectively a beta...so right now, you pretty much have the basic stuff in the game.  There is a thread on the Forums regarding the use of copyrighted material...this can hamper some of the more popular games" being reproduced.

The Ugly:  The "game room" is...well...empty...there's the table...but no walls
date: no floor...just the table (this is something that is added later).\n\nThat's really it...I enjoy the games so far
recommended: I hope that more is added in and that copyright holders allow for their products to be added to the Steam Workshop (when that's added)."

reviewText:
It's a fun way to play board games with friends who live far away.

My first impression was that the game is a little clunky, and it is. But it captures the charm of actually sitting around a table playing a game, in a way that other online board games do not. Playing board games with friends is more about the social experience than about rock-solid competitive play IMO, so I'll take some clunkiness in exchange for that charm.

The workshop integration is awesome and also helps makes the game.

reviewText: First off, let me start by saying I've been playing Table Top Simulator with it was in Early Access. Now that Table Top Simulator is out of E.A. I felt like I could write my review of the game. Table Top Simulator is a great sandbox! The community and mods are fantastic! I mainly use Table Top Simulator for my D&D group, during our sessions. All I need is Table Top Simulator, my laptop, and a TV. Using all the wonderful mods in Steam Workshop, I can create great 3-D dungeons, towns, and etc for my players. Uploading mods to the Steam Workshop is with ease, in my D&D group we have a player whose been working on models for our D&D games and exciting to see what she develops. Using Table Top Simulator is a great visual for encounters and dungeons, among a long list of other things.  We've even used Table Top Simulator for playing our D&D sessions even over the internet, all in the comfort of our own homes. It ran really smooth and there was little to no issues we encountered. The Dev's also release updates quite often and it's exciting what new content they add.\n\nI don't only use it for D&D, though that's what I mainly use it for. Users have been able to upload, in the Steam Workshop, actual board games. Such games as Star Wars: X-WING, Beytral At The House On The Hill, Settlers Of Catan, and etc. It makes playing games with friends easy and still as fun as if you all got together. I would be lying though, if I said it didn't take away the feeling of actually interacting with your friends and seeing their emotions. Although Table Top Simulator has made playing games with friends over the internet easy and fun, it still cannot replace the moments of sitting at your dinning table and playing all together. Given that, I would still recommend Table Top Simulator, 10/10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI seriously didn't think I'd love this game as much as I do. You'll think at first is the price really worth it for a virtual board game?". You're not just buying a board game. You can play literally any board game you want with this and make up your own rules. Not only that but you can also play any card game at all be it Texas Hold 'Em or Magic the Gathering. You're even able to make and upload your own cards. Not only THAT but you're also able to build and manage your own dungeons and dragons roleplay session. The concept is there and they plan on expanding on it but as it stands it's probably the best virtual tabletop I've had the honor of playing Pathfinder on. It's such a simple idea but it's all the little things the developers are doing right that makes this game worth it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tabletop Simulator is, without a doubt, one of the most impressive early access games on the market today. With near constant weekly updates, swift and amazing customer service. This is the pinnacle of what can be done by a two person development team.

Tabletop Simulator features the ability to make your own custom games, play them with friends, family, and even enemies if you so desire!

Key features include:
Multiplayer support, couch co-op via hotseat mode, singleplayer mode, custom model support, voice chat, text chat and of course, Steam Workshop.

Remember, this game is best with friends, either online or offline, there is no AI and there is no current possibility of this.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the game that is truly for everyone, because it has something for everyone. It brings to the table what couldn't be brought to the table of the inernet before, something many of the internet citizens have desired to do with each other since the invention of it: Flip a table.

...and play a board game or two while they're at it.

Easy modding support, especially for cards. That along with the sandbox nature of the game makes this an amazing find if you're looking for a multiplayer game of ANY sort. Because this is so many games in one.

As it is constantly updated, every quirk I have had about this game has been removed. However, if you have low speed on your internet, may want to ease up on the activity on the board while online.

11/10. Nuff said.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game provided a fun alternative to going to a tabletop game store and spending 40 bucks on a board game that will only get use once or twice a month for a few months.

The game is easy to mod and so long as you know what you're doing, you can create your own decks of cards with ease and editing the model logic is simple with some rendering software or experience doing so.

My only gripe is that you cannot publish privately to Steam right now. I have a custom game that I made that I want to release to my friends but don't want to be posted publically at this point... it would be nice to be able to use steam's workshop for the release instead of having to manually update their files.


Overall though, once you get the controls down, this is a good option for trying out new desktop games before you buy them or if you are trying to juggle busy schedules.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very fun Simulator with great multiplayer. The game is a simple concept, but the details add immensely to the fun and value during multiplayer. Host a server easily or join one. Quickly choose between lots of common games (Chess, Checkers etc.). I play cards a lot- the host can quickly deal cards to everyone and shuffle simply by clicking. You can see where each player's cursor is, and you can drag and drop betting chips. You can chat easily during the game through voice or chat. Little noises liek chips clicking and cards shuffling add to the game. You can manipulate the game chips which adds to the physicality" of the player-game interaction.

"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is probably the most interesting use of a physics engine that I've seen so far. Rather than limit you to a series of 'planned' interactions with the 'game' the engine merely responds to how you move the pieces. So this is basically a true 'sandbox' in the sense that you can do whatever you want and the engine doesn't get in the way if possible. It might be a little frustrating for people who are looking for a dedicated poker game, or a dedicated chess game, etc etc, but for tabletop gamers....

There's an RPG set that looks like it can be used for D&D, GURPS, etc with an in-the-works 'character sheet;' could this seriously mean that D&D could move to virtual pen and paper?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game where what you do can do things as though you and your friends were at an actual table playing whatever comes to mind, ranging from board games (such as Chess, Go, and Reversi), card games, to rpg role playing. All without the mess and streamlined actions for dealing and cleaning up cards. It even has gravity settings and blocks to play with.

Further possibilities are added when you throw in board and deck importing into the mix. You're basically capable of playing any board game that exists as long as you or someone else knows how to make it. The possibilities are almost limitless, and this may even allow for new tabletop games to come to life, allowing for a potential whole new wave of board games.

It can be a brilliant game for classic tabletop fun or for complete hilarity, allowing you to do things you wouldn't normally be able to do in your house, and even allowing you to do table flips. It's your choice.

Probably one of the most simplistically innovative ideas for a game out there. I recommend it to the highest degree.
Oh I almost forgot, make sure you have friends to play this with- you could always play online, but it's nothing like having you and a bunch of your friends at the same table messing around.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite a nice little game. Basically a board game simulator with the added fun of physics to create a more Sandbox like feel to the game.

Out of the box, the game comes with a couple of popular board games to get you started: Backgammon, Cards (Limitless amount of games here, although the game does come with Poker chips should we want to partake any money centred card games), chess, checkers and even an RPG dungeons and dragons style kit so you can create dungeon advantures.

Where the game really excels at is the community behind the game as well, a large array of additional games can be downloaded for free from the Steam Workshop with cards and custom model support you can play a number of games.

The game also comes with internet multiplayer support can you can mess about with your friends over a virtual table top.

Oh and yes, you can flip tables. :)

Nifty game, would reccomend purchasing if it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you have any love for card games, board games, or even pen-and-paper RPGs, this is as close as it gets to the real thing.

Everything is affected by solid and reliable physics, and there's very little restriction to how you interact with the game pieces. You're open to just not playing the game at all and just screwing around with the pieces. Stage a soap opera with chess pieces, who cares.

It's wide-open to custom content. You can make custom card decks with just image files, you can import models for custom figurines and game pieces, make your own custom boards, and it can all be uploaded to the Steam Workshop. Try to count how many variations of Monopoly you see.

The online play is simple, stable, smooth, and the most well-synced of any physics-centric game I've played.

With all that together, you can play basically any game that can be played on a table. 'Cept for games with moving parts. Like Mouse Trap or something.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the game that is truly for everyone, because it has something for everyone. It brings to the table what couldn't be brought to the table of the inernet before, something many of the internet citizens have desired to do with each other since the invention of it: Flip a table.

...and play a board game or two while they're at it.

Easy modding support, especially for cards. That along with the sandbox nature of the game makes this an amazing find if you're looking for a multiplayer game of ANY sort. Because this is so many games in one.

As it is constantly updated, every quirk I have had about this game has been removed. However, if you have low speed on your internet, may want to ease up on the activity on the board while online.

11/10. Nuff said.

reviewText:
Tabletop Simulator is very much what you and your playgroup make it to be. Some people will play this game for an hour with their friends, get frustrated/bored at Uno, flip the table and seldom if ever return. Others will spend months map-building, learning, and enjoying a large breadth of games-- a unique experience unavailable anywhere else online. With dedication and patience you can make this game into something amazing for your playgroup.

Pros
Extremely customizable
Large modding community
Play any game with anyone
Endless replayability
The only platform of its kind
Cons
Relies on actively accessing various webpages for textures (can break things for users with slow net or country restrictions)
Relatively small playing community (It's hard to just find randoms in a server/forum and join a game)
Memory limitations in the client prevent large amounts of textures to be loaded simulataneously
The physics are not perfect, making some more interactive games frustrating
You will only have as much fun as the combined effort of everyone in your playgroup working to learn and create new content-- at the end of the day it's a social game and you need good friends to play it.
Conclusion

This game will either be an amazing journey for you and your friends or it won't be worth your time installing (which isn't very long at all). In any case, best of luck.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tabletop simulator is an awesome platform for playing board- or cardgames with your friends. It's not for playing with random people online but rather for playing with friends or family. It's easy to use and with plenty of workshop content readily available, and if you are a little creative it is easy to create custom games or even invent your very own.

The only thing that it needs is ingame customizable time keeping, like a one-click x-minute timer and I'd be able to create any game I want in it.

Now if only you could buy a bundle when you already own the game, then I'd be buying the crap out of this game to gift to all my friends. Steam, PLEASE make this possible...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since I was a child I have been fascinated with board and card games. I can think of no better game than Tabletop Simulator that mirrors this experience. With all the Steam Workshop items as well as the included content this game will give you hours of fun and excitement. If you are into board games this is a game for you!

There are some issues with this game that still need to be worked out. Currently, the multiplayer portion of the game is still somewhat broken. You can check out my frustrations with this multiplayer here ( http://steamcommunity.com/app/286160/discussions/0/626329186887989015/ )

Like any game on Steam that features multiplayer you WILL ecounter a troll/griefer. The one server I was able to get connected to turned on his mic to some of the most hideous screams, music, sounds, etc until we were able to kick and ban him. Thankfully, there is an option to remove/ban players. Also, if you haven't disabled table flipping there is the potential for someone to come into the game just to take everything out in one single table flipping move.

With all that said I still recomend this game. I have had so much fun playing that I turned three of my friends on to this game already. I look forward to seeing the multiplayer connectivity issues corrected in future updates and as always playing more community created content from the Steam Workshop.

TL;DR

+ Awesome Game
-  Multiplayer has issues

Now if only you could buy a bundle when you already own the game, then I'd be buying the crap out of this game to gift to all my friends. Steam, PLEASE make this possible...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since I was a child I have been fascinated with board and card games. I can think of no better game than Tabletop Simulator that mirrors this experience. With all the Steam Workshop items as well as the included content this game will give you hours of fun and excitement. If you are into board games this is a game for you!

There are some issues with this game that still need to be worked out. Currently, the multiplayer portion of the game is still somewhat broken. You can check out my frustrations with this multiplayer here ( http://steamcommunity.com/app/286160/discussions/0/626329186887989015/ )

Like any game on Steam that features multiplayer you WILL ecounter a troll/griefer. The one server I was able to get connected to turned on his mic to some of the most hideous screams, music, sounds, etc until we were able to kick and ban him. Thankfully, there is an option to remove/ban players. Also, if you haven't disabled table flipping there is the potential for someone to come into the game just to take everything out in one single table flipping move.

With all that said I still recomend this game. I have had so much fun playing that I turned three of my friends on to this game already. I look forward to seeing the multiplayer connectivity issues corrected in future updates and as always playing more community created content from the Steam Workshop.

TL;DR

+ Awesome Game
-  Multiplayer has issues

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is probably the most interesting use of a physics engine that I've seen so far. Rather than limit you to a series of 'planned' interactions with the 'game' the engine merely responds to how you move the pieces. So this is basically a true 'sandbox' in the sense that you can do whatever you want and the engine doesn't get in the way if possible. It might be a little frustrating for people who are looking for a dedicated poker game, or a dedicated chess game, etc etc, but for tabletop gamers....

There's an RPG set that looks like it can be used for D&D, GURPS, etc with an in-the-works 'character sheet;' could this seriously mean that D&D could move to virtual pen and paper?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's Gmod for board games!

Graphics:
The graphics aren't anything to shout about, but they are decent and nice to look at.

Sound:
Agains, nothing to shout about.  There's no music, so supply your own if need be.  The sounds that do come up are nice and sound like they should.

Control:
I use keyboard/mouse, but it seems it also supports controller.  You can move anythign and everything around and there are no issues that I found.

Gameplay:
This is where the game shines!  Not only are there several games already included, it supports Steam Workshop, which has LOTS of user created games as well as full recreations of established boardgames such adn Monopoly and Risk!  There are so many, I don't think you could get through them all, though there are a few user created ones that you might wanna pass up for various reasons.  But with up to player 8 online support and extensive Hosting tools, you and friends will have a HUGE blast with this game!  There is even support for Dungeons and Dragons miniatures, so you can host an online D&D session, which is great for those who want to roleplay, but don't live near people who do!

I urge everyone to get this game!  This is the most awesome program for boardgame lovers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tabletop simulator is one of the most fun games to ever be put on steam,  The possibilities for this are endless.
You can play ANY tabletop game you wish,  And if it does not exist in the workshop you can simply create it yourself with the in game editor which is very simple to use.

Being yet another early access game I was a little reluctant to play it,  As I have had a few mixed feelings about other early access games.  But this works perfectly and I have never had so much fun with a game.

There are still a few very minor bugs but they still don't take away any of the fun.

If you like tabletop games I highly recommend this,  And if you don't. I am sure you will after playing this.
I will confidently give this game a solid 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tableflip Simulator.
But in all seriousness, this is amazing. True dedication and work has been put into this, and it truly does what it aims to do, and it continues to do it better.

PROS:
Play with your friends.
Play the games you love (Monopoly, Munchkin, etc. Find them on the workshop)
Great piece control and system

CONS:
Worried about copyright issues as far as games being put up by users on the workshop.
Trying to do multiple things at once(I.E. zooming in on a piece you are holding) tends to be buggy for now. Not a true issue though.
Initial load into a room is slow even on a high end computer due to intensive memory load and image processing. After this there are no real problems.

EDIT: The recent update (v2.7 on 9/19/2014) fixes many of the memory issues, so if this was holding you back from buying this, DON'T LET IT :D

What I would like to see:
Character sheet support
Piece interaction support and health bars/stats applied to pieces. (I.E. Elf Attack-> Orc for 12 damage. -12 image over Orc, health bar, if known/visible, drains an appropriate amount.)
EFFECTS! ALL THE EFFECTS! EXPLOSIONS! FOIL CARDS! CARDS THAT PROJECT 3D HOLOGRAM" MODELS!
Custom rooms

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In order to understand this game, You have to be a gamer. And not the normal gamer of today, one whose in a college frat playing cod, or a 10 year old who screamed his head off until his parents got him that M rated game... This is a game about imagination, Simplicity, Friendship, and most importantly... Strategy. This simulator allows you to run servers that can play board games. Games like Monopoly, Risk, Life, Ticket to Ride, Carcassone, and many many others. But it also allows you to run card games like Cards against Humanity, or Apples to Apples, or Uno, and again, many many others.
And of course this game allows you to play any RPG dungeoun crawler/adeventure/Story-driven game your little heart can imagine. In my years of gaming, This is the most complete version of the physical, becoming the Digital. And i adore it.

If you like playing board games, RPGs, or card games AT ALL, play this game. Any gamer should play this game. Its the greatest thing gamers could ask for.

Also the graphics are really good...

10/10 take all the tens!!!

reviewText:
A physics sandbox simulating a table for the purpose of all manner of tabletop games - Board Games, Card Games, Pen-and-Paper RPGs, Jigsaw Puzzles, etc.  With an extensive Workshop selection of user-made content many popular childhood games can be found.
I've used it to host table-top RPGs and card games and even just sitting around BSing with friends is enjoyable.  With some playful props thrown in and everyone chatting, It definately feels as close to sitting around a table as it can get without engaging webcams.

There'sd no AI so rules are not artifically enforced, if a player wants to cheat by moving out of turn or swapping the places of a Knight and a Rook - just like in real life - there's nothing stopping them but honest.  However, there are physics mechanics in play to keep objects from slopping around the board.  Pieces can be hard- and soft-locked in place so accidental nudging doesn't ruin a carefully laid board and pieces can optionally snap to a grid.  -  Just enough framework to allow things to work well and avoid chaos without being restrictive and 'too much like a videogame'.

I highly recommend TTS to anyone who enjoys any manner of tabletop games.  I was skeptical but saw that the game had potential and am very pleased to say that it's lived up to my expectations and surpassed them.

Add a few friends to the mix and plastic peices on a piece of coloured wood can easily become a heated duel or an epic adventure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's Gmod for board games!

Graphics:
The graphics aren't anything to shout about, but they are decent and nice to look at.

Sound:
Agains, nothing to shout about.  There's no music, so supply your own if need be.  The sounds that do come up are nice and sound like they should.

Control:
I use keyboard/mouse, but it seems it also supports controller.  You can move anythign and everything around and there are no issues that I found.

Gameplay:
This is where the game shines!  Not only are there several games already included, it supports Steam Workshop, which has LOTS of user created games as well as full recreations of established boardgames such adn Monopoly and Risk!  There are so many, I don't think you could get through them all, though there are a few user created ones that you might wanna pass up for various reasons.  But with up to player 8 online support and extensive Hosting tools, you and friends will have a HUGE blast with this game!  There is even support for Dungeons and Dragons miniatures, so you can host an online D&D session, which is great for those who want to roleplay, but don't live near people who do!

I urge everyone to get this game!  This is the most awesome program for boardgame lovers!

reviewText: As many before me have already said, Tabletop Simulator is less a game than it is a tool for playing games. The base game includes your standard tabletop classics, including playing cards, dominoes, and chess and checkers sets, but you can download other games from the workshop, such as Monopoly, Uno, and Cards Against Humanity. While the singleplayer part of the game is fine, with things such as jigsaw puzzles and solitaire, the options are limited. Playing with at least one other person opens up many more options, such as Chess, Checkers, Go, and multi-player card games, and it's even more fun playing a big game with a group of friends or even with other random people online. At $20, the price is rather steep and it's probably a good idea to wait for a sale, but if you think about it, it only costs as much as an actual board game or two. That said, Tabletop Simulator is very good, and I recommend it. Play on!

reviewText:
This game makes Game Night so much easier!

I have a group of friends that tries to get together regularly to play games. We can't always make it happen, because life and all that.

We all picked up this game, and suddenly Game Night happens much more often! It's so nice to be able to hop online and get into whatever board game suits your fancy.

The tools for making your own games are also pretty robust, which I appreciate as a designer. Even if you aren't playing games with a group, it's still an excellent way to quickly prototype and test game ideas.

reviewText: Honestly, whatever flaws this gem might have, it is an amazing game for the possibilities it gives you. Have a friend who moved away but you loved playing Risk together, or 40k, or even just want to play som good old Monopoly? This can take care of it for you. The intergrated Workshop gives you one game that gives you hundreds of other games. You dont have to buy this game and that game, and that other game there too, to get what this game provides. Fancy a game of Star Wars chess? Done. Monopoly? Done. Risk? Done. Heroquest? Done. Blackjack? Done. Even goddang Guess Who? Done. The sheer versatility, the options...11/10.
